US State-level data including test results

Source: R/covidtracking_com.R
covidtracker_data.Rd

Get data from the COVID tracking project https://covidtracking.com/ including daily historical data on testing results, hospitalizations, and deaths.

covidtracker_data()

Value

A tidy tbl_df

Details

From the COVID Tracking Project website:

The COVID Tracking Project collects information from 50 US states, the District of Columbia, and 5 other US territories to provide the most comprehensive testing data we can collect for the novel coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2. We attempt to report positive and negative results, pending tests, and total people tested for each state or district currently reporting that data.

See also

  • https://covidtracking.com/about-tracker/

  • https://covidtracking.com/notes/

Other data-import: apple_mobility_data(), beoutbreakprepared_data(), cdc_aggregated_projections(), cdc_excess_deaths(), coronanet_government_response_data(), cov_glue_lineage_data(), cov_glue_newick_data(), descartes_mobility_data(), ecdc_data(), eu_data_cache_data(), google_mobility_data(), government_policy_timeline(), healthdata_projections_data(), jhu_data(), jhu_us_data(), kff_icu_beds(), nytimes_county_data(), param_estimates_published(), us_county_geo_details(), us_county_health_rankings(), us_healthcare_capacity(), us_hospital_details(), us_state_distancing_policy(), usa_facts_data()

Other case-tracking: align_to_baseline(), beoutbreakprepared_data(), bulk_estimate_Rt(), combined_us_cases_data(), ecdc_data(), estimate_Rt(), eu_data_cache_data(), jhu_data(), nytimes_county_data(), owid_data(), plot_epicurve(), usa_facts_data()

Examples

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

res = covidtracker_data()
colnames(res)
#> [1] "date"         "state"        "positive"     "negative"     "pending"     
#> [6] "hospitalized" "death"        "dateChecked"  "fips"        
dim(res)
#> [1] 4217    9
dplyr::glimpse(res)
#> Rows: 4,217
#> Columns: 9
#> $ date         <date> 2020-05-19, 2020-05-19, 2020-05-19, 2020-05-19, 2020-05…
#> $ state        <chr> "AK", "AL", "AR", "AS", "AZ", "CA", "CO", "CT", "DC", "D…
#> $ positive     <int> 399, 12376, 4923, 0, 14566, 81795, 22202, 38430, 7434, 8…
#> $ negative     <int> 35981, 145190, 88778, 124, 147005, 1257521, 109131, 1470…
#> $ pending      <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, 1369, NA, NA, NA…
#> $ hospitalized <int> NA, 1453, 535, NA, 1746, NA, 3899, 10946, NA, NA, 8744, …
#> $ death        <int> 10, 504, 102, 0, 704, 3334, 1224, 3472, 400, 304, 2129, …
#> $ dateChecked  <dttm> 2020-05-19 20:00:00, 2020-05-19 20:00:00, 2020-05-19 20…
#> $ fips         <chr> "00002", "00001", "00005", "00060", "00004", "00006", "0…

# Hospitalizations by day in Maryland
covidtracker_data() %>%
    dplyr::filter(state=='MD') %>%
    add_incidence_column(count_column='hospitalized') %>%
    ggplot(aes(x=date,y=inc)) + geom_smooth() +
    ylab("New Hospitalizations per day") +
    ggtitle('Hospitalizations in Maryland', subtitle = 'From covidtracker')
#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x'
#> Warning: Removed 22 rows containing non-finite values (stat_smooth).
